reviewText:
As a child, I played a ton of a little board game called Hero Quest. While many have attested that this game is very similar, I can tell you that a lot of the tiles used in this game as well as the monsters are EXACT copies. However, there are some differences.

In this game, you play as 3 characters, all of whom have different strengths and weaknesses. They move along a set of tiles like a board game in a turn-based strategy RPG style. The story in this game is very light with no real purpose.

Having said that, I absolutely recommend this game to any board game fanatics or Dungeons and Dragons fans out there that wish they could play solo. The levels are fast-paced, fun, and the abilities and attacks are very chance-based, similar to rolling dice.

I absolutely loved my playthrough of this game and I hope a sequel comes out at some point!
voteText: 34 of 35 people (97%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
First Impressions:

This isn't a bad game, though it is pretty linear and dumbed down compared to some other dungeon RPGs I've played (Claustrophobia: The Downward Struggle, Desktop Dungeons, Dungeons of Dredmor, Warhammer Quest, etc.).  Essentially, you control 3 heroes and are tasked with clearing a level.  Afterwards, you can use the money you've earned to buy equipment, spells, and some other goodies.  If you're looking for an in-depth and complex dungeon crawler, this is most certainly not it.  If games like Dungeons of Dredmor tend to overwhelm you with too many available options, then this might be more your speed.  In the end, $5 isn't a bad price for what you're getting here, though other games certainly do the genre a bit more justice.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JaVzmzu5NkA
voteText: 19 of 22 people (86%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This is PC port of a mobile version of a very simple board game. Mobile is the key word here. While it could be ok for times when you're sitting with your tablet and you're bored out of your mind, there's actually no reason to get in on PC.

There's really not much to the game, you just click on stuff and it dies. Unless you're unlucky, then it kills you. Also, once in a while you pick up a bag of gold that actually takes away some gold from you(?!), or lose hit point or a turn for no reason whatsoever, beacuse the skull of fate, yay. There are about 10 levels and a pesky turn limit to finish them in.

Graphics are kinda nice, but let's be honest: it only looks RPG-like. There's no character creation, no progression, weapons are actually a single-use items, etc.

Buy only if you want to support indie developers or on a massive sale when you desperately need something to do for a single evening.

reviewText:
HeroQuest, the board game, but not licensed by Games Workshop. The result is that the price isn't hiked up, which isn't a bad thing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wh_8iD1Gj74

There's a slight mobile game feel and a condensed scope, but it's the same grand RPG feel of old, otherwise. Different classes march through a dungeon, use their feats to defeat a range of monsters; discover traps, secret doors and so on. Additional equipment and spells can be traded for gold, on the way to more adventures in a self-explanatory, explorative environment.

A flood of nostalgia for the board game fan.

reviewText: Mobile clone of the classic HeroQuest boardgame. Art is pretty good, particularly the portraits on the board - the rest of the game isn't much to write home about.\n\nThe UI is clunky / slow, there is not much in way of story or mission briefings and the game tried to alter / re-invent what HeroQuest did but failed by adding various random events that make you lose HP because bad dice rolls". HeroQuest was random
date:
but never this random. Rolling how much HP are restored for example or randomly lose all APs or losing a turn entirely are pretty common in Dark Quest. Needless to say: not very fun.

The game itself is pretty much the same as it has always been - uncover areas and funnel enemies into small areas and narrow tunnels to avoid getting overrun. It gets old pretty quickly and seemingly was designed with heal potion-spam in mind - which probably has something to do with IAP on the mobile version of this.

Good for 15 minutes of nostalgia
recommended: not much worth after those 15 minutes are over."

reviewText:
Dark Quest, for better or for worse, is an indie clone of HeroQuest, both in aesthetics and gameplay. Unfortunately, it's hampered by incredibly poor writing, a clumsy UI, a painful bug that made the game significantly harder and more awkward, and a failure to measure up to the 1989 boardgame in almost every way.

Since it's the core of the gameplay, there's no real getting around it - Dark Quest is HeroQuest in many ways. However, many of the relevant numbers are hidden from the player, you are only given control of three heroes instead of four, the fairly wide variety of magic spells for the Wizard (and Elf, who isn't in this game) from the board game is mostly missing, items are all purchased or looted consumables instead of HeroQuest's variety of purchasable equipment, mostly-found consumables, and found artifacts, and there's only eight (or nine? I'm honestly unsure, because the game is bad at communicating things and I wasn't writing it down...) quests instead of the original HeroQuest's twelve. Also there's a turn limit on each quest, but it's so generous that I never felt I was in risk of hitting it, so that's kind of a non-point.

Several of these differences I mentioned are related to the clumsy UI, which makes selecting heroes who aren't on the same screen as each other awkward (unless there's a hotkey for it that I'm missing), as you need to scroll over to and click on them, and frequently gives little information - item/spell descriptions are there and useful, but knowing any stats other than BP for heroes and monsters is impossible except by guesswork. Similarly, how traps are detected was never entirely clear to me even by the end of the game - moving the dwarf near" them seemed to detect them after his move
date: but it wasn't always clear what determined whether or not he was "near" enough for it to work. When buying things in town

column17: nor does the game have real configuration options for doing things like changing the volume
column18: just turning it on or off. Also
column19: while you can quickly click through most windows to speed up game play
column20: you're stuck at the "roll the skull of fate" screen for a good few seconds before it becomes enabled to click on
column21: slowing down the game notably whenever it randomly happens. Ultimately
column22: you'll spend almost as much time fighting the UI as having fun fighting Azkallor's minions.\n\nThe bug I mentioned was simple
column23: but rather terrible - you couldn't use any items that came after a blank slot in your inventory. Given that you couldn't move items around in your inventory
column25: this put you in the awkward position of using the last item in an inventory slot disabling your access to any items in later slots for the rest of the quest. There seemed to be a related bug where the description of items in your inventory would also be wrong
column26: with the description of the item your mouse was over belonging to a different item in your inventory. If you knew what your items did
column29: just awkward.\n\nAs far as the poor writing goes
column30: the story in this game is obviously not the draw
column31: much as it wasn't for HeroQuest
column32: but the in-game English script was incredibly badly written
column36: et cetera. It was fairly distracting
column37: and the game really could have used an editing pass.\n\nIn the end
column38: I actually had some fun with Dark Quest because it was a take on a good game design
column39: and it reminded me of the fun times I had playing the original HeroQuest board game as a kid. However
column41: and not because I was blinded by nostalgia - a straight adaptation of the board game would have been a better game
column42: and almost none of the changes were
column44: for the better. It's also rather short and without much replay value
column45: as I completed all of the quests included in the game in around two and a half hours of play. So

reviewText:
Dark Quest is a turn-based board game-esque fantasy strategy game, loosely based off of the old Hero Quest board game. In it, you play as three characters (Warrior, Dwarf, and Wizard) seeking to make your way through a series of dungeons to complete a set of quests which are posed to you. Along the way, you need to deal with traps, secret doors, and collecting gold to upgrade your equipment/spells back in town.

The game is quite short, taking roughly 3 hours to 100%. Combat is largely random, and there are other random events which can lead to damage to your characters, which can occasionally feel a little imbalanced because some runs you won't be touched, while others you end up getting into dire straits rather quickly.

It's moderately fun, but in my case it's likely at least partially due to nostalgia from enjoying Hero Quest itself. Consider the gameplay, and the length of the game, and choose a price point which seems appropriate to you.

reviewText:
Good, wholesome, simple fun. Another reviewer mentioned Hero Quest; close, but not quite...

Pros:
- Fun (that's the point, right?)
- Simple (can dive in/out without switching gears too much)
- Clean/Elegant (even supports 2550x1440!)

Cons:
- Character development is zero - Seems you level once per dungeon (gain HP and/or other stats), but there are no numbers or even notifications to this... A simple character sheet would go a really long way here.
- As with above, seems items/spells don't really grow in strength, you can just buy more. All of them are consumable (even armor, swords, etc.; all are one-shots)
- Small bugs - (E.g. item icons may not match actual item selected)
- Random skull of fate" occasionally interrupts. Lose 20 gold
date: or one HP. Mildly annoying.\n\nA patch or two should clear some of these right up
voteText: a worthy $5 gem.\n\nPro tip: disable "confirm move""

reviewText:
It's Heroquest for steam
They literally stole the game, well at least 90% of it and even the pictures from the boardgame.  Found it funny at the end credits when they said who the art guy was,.yeeahhhh sure.

Pros:
The game is pretty simple, you only need to use the left mouse button.
It is interesting for a bit but after an hour or two looses its luster.


Cons:

Its a Herquest Knockoff they are taking credit for on steam.
The game campaign is pretty simple, way to simple.
Glitches:  The game eventually tells you on your items bar the wrong messages.  Your Axe might say its a potion  on the text confusing the hell out of you what to actually click because it may actually be the AXE or POTION 50/50 sucks.  Sometimes you buy items and they show in inventory then you go into the next dungeon and they are missing.
Going to the Innkeeper does absolutely nothing for you other than you loose  140 gold.  Whenever you go back into the dungeons even without the innkeeper to heal you/rejuvenate you - You will be at 100% health anyway.
The Village you go to after every completed dungeon is ridiculous, there is almost no point other than buying life elixir potions which give HP.  All the villagers such as the Blacksmith, potion seller, and Magic teacher never have new items along the progression of the game.  As soon as you leave a dungeon your in town and the same short tutorial points you to buy more trap disarms, its annoying it even does it when your full and cant buy anymore.  The Old man in town has options where you can ask him what trials await your next dungeon?!?  Good idea right?? Wrong, he says the same thing over and over again and it never changes throughout the game.  Whoever coded/made this did a ♥♥♥♥ poor job.

*spoiler*

The ending sucks.  You go threw not a ton of dungeons but an ok amount just to get to the last boss who is not even the Evil Wizard that's been toying with your lives.  You know why?  Because they stole the artwork and didn't have a wizard piece to use on the board.  You fight a guy thats easily kill able using firewall spells just stand back a bit and let him walk threw and he dies.  After last boss dies, your told too bad you failed everyone in the kingdom died while you where fighting in the dungeons" then it ends.....hoo friggin ray.


Not a spoiler-
Basically buy this on sale its not worth even the small amount they are asking.  Get it if you want it before they are sued.

On a side note: This game could actually work very well as it has tons of potential its just not being utilized by the right people."

reviewText:
It only takes a few minutes of playing Dark Quest to realise how much of a minimum-effort shovelware mobile port it is. After a couple of hours you may wish you'd never even heard of it, let alone spent good money. The gameplay is extremely basic, the mechanics have all the depth of a puddle, there is absolutely no character progression, the visuals are repetitive and the interface is clunky, when it works at all.

This is a game that so obviously wants to be HeroQuest but lacks any of the playability and charm of that classic boardgame.

No matter how cheap, Dark Quest is simply not worth your time.

reviewText:
4/10

This game was Juuuust a bit less than I could have imagined. Pardon the sexual conotations, but this game is the equivalent of a quickie without release. Not bad, maybe even a little fun, but just not satisfying at all.
If you are a fan of 'Heroes Quest' and this is going cheap, it is probably worth getting. If not despite it being a 'working' game I just can't recommend.

Pros:
- Decent release. Not many bugs or problems.
- Can play a level in a short amount of time.
- Has some usable items to make the game a 'little' more interesting.
- Has some strategic elements

Cons:
- Lacks anything to draw you in.
- Lacks. There's just not much there.

Other:
- Dated Graphics
- Has a strange fate thing that triggers constantly to add random effects. (Predominantly a character loses or gains a life). Not too sure about the context, the story content etc is somewhat lacking.

reviewText:
This is a short, simple game sure but it comes at a very low price and it delivers a solid enough return of fun for your money.

If you've played the old boardgame HeroQuest then you'll rapidly recognise this game which has very similar underpinings. The tactics are pretty simple but they are there in enough quantity to make the game fun and the monsters piled high enough on later levels to make it less than trivial to win through.

There's an annoying bug with using items from your inventory where they frequently stop responding to mouse clicks but you can trigger them with the hotkeys 1-6 so it's not gamebreaking. Mind you, these hotkey aren't mentioned anywhere and it could do with hotkeys for some other common actions.

reviewText:
This is a PC port of a casual mobile game that's meant to be a clone of Warhammer Quest. Unfortunately, this game is just not fun.

Bad:
-The interface is clunky and not adjusted to PC at all.
-Gameplay is shallow, repetitive, and consistently meh.
-random elements don't really carry over form a boardgame perspective; especially when the interface and gameplay is already bad
-Combat devolves into a game of drinking potions
-Story is toilet paper thin; It's basically Kill bad wizard...for reasons"


Good:
-Sound and music is nice and gives a good reactive feel to combat
-Art is done well. Probably the best part of the game"

A brief but entertaining romp in the vien of Warhammer Quest and Hero Quest.
Short, cheap and fun.
It lacks depth and it is only a few mission yet for fans of WHQ and HQ or boardgames like Descent it is still a fun little romp.
